etymologies: late Middle English: via Old French from medieval Latin, based on tenere ‘to hold’; so named because the tenor part was allotted (and therefore ‘held’) the melody

definitions: a singing voice between baritone and alto or countertenor, the highest of the ordinary adult male range.
shortDefinitions: singing voice between baritone and alto or countertenor

definitions: a singer with a tenor voice.
a part written for a tenor voice.
an instrument, especially a saxophone, trombone, tuba, or viol, of the lowest pitch but one in its family
the largest and deepest bell of a ring or set.
shortDefinitions: largest and deepest bell of ring

etymologies: Middle English: from Old French tenour, from Latin tenor ‘course, substance, import of a law’, from tenere ‘to hold’

definitions: the general meaning, sense, or content of something

examples.text: the general tenor of the debate

shortDefinitions: general meaning, sense, or content of something

definitions: a settled or prevailing character or direction, especially the course of a person's life or habits

examples.text: the even tenor of life in the kitchen was disrupted the following day

shortDefinitions: settled or prevailing character or direction

definitions: the actual wording of a document.
the time that must elapse before a bill of exchange or promissory note becomes due for payment.
shortDefinitions: time that must elapse before bill of exchange or promissory note becomes due for payment
